transcript.content: [~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
It's not going to be what he thinks...

Listen. Donna Air and her zoo-owner boyfriend Damian Aspinall intend to place their baby daughter in the care of a gorilla. The couple plan to put Freya, who was born in September, in the gorilla enclosure at the zoo near Canterbury. They will then let her be carried off by the female of the group. Neither parent has any qualms about letting their daughter be taken off despite five keepers being killed by animals at Howletts and its sister park since 1980.
I don't understand. What do you mean?
Well, that's it. That's the news...
It's a newborn baby and they're going to put it in a gorilla... But I mean...
Well he said, "Why would I not trust them? I know them. I grew up with them. They're my friends."
Yeah, but it... but... I'm not saying that they're, they're aggressive, but it might roll over on it or something.
I don't, well, I don't know. Take it up with the, uh... with them. I mean, Donna Air is not the brightest spark in the box...
No, but I, I don't think...
And it would seem her husband is...
I don't think, you know, the... that would en... she'd endanger... I mean, they must know something we don't. I still don't... I still can't believe they're just going to leave the gorilla with it.
Mmm.
Meanwhile...
Why would you though? But, but why would you? Even though it says well it's...
Cheaper than a babysitter?
[Ricky laughs]
Well, I don't know. Well, how cheap is a gorilla babysitter? Karl knows, cause there's probably some sort of organization.
Right. Are we, uh...
Competition, then. Come on, then. What is it? Oh...
Songs of Phrase. Eh...
Remind us of this?
Eh... we've got the film one coming up later as well.
[Ricky groans]
But Songs of Phrase is the one where I take a popular phrase from the show.
Well no, it's not a popular phrase from the show, it's sometimes something you said once. "There's this hairy Chinese kid."
Yeah, and I get all different bits of songs. So, you know, I make up that sentence and you have to email in with the artists that you hear.
Why, what's the popular phase then? What's this? What's this popular phrase that's sweeping the nation?
Uh... it's what we talked about last week.
Go on.
It's, uh, "me girlfriend had a problem with her marrow."
[Ricky snickers]
Right...
Yeah.
All right.
Okay. She wasn't your girlfriend.
Well, yeah, but I couldn't find...
Oh, okay.
...blind date or whatever. So uh, so seven, seven artists it's taken to make up this Songs of Phrase.
"Me girlfriend had a problem with her marrow." That's at least eight, so...
Well, maybe not.
I think I've managed it in seven. Anyway here we go.
What are the artists? What are the names of the artists? Get a pen and paper, make a note.
What artists are you hearing here?
[Music] "MY/GIRLFRIEND/HAD/PROBLEM/WITH HER/MARROW"
[Ricky laughs]
Very good.
Okay. And what's...
What are the artists?
[Music] "MY/GIRLFRIEND/HAD/PROBLEM/WITH HER/MARROW"
Very good.
"My girlfriend had a problem with her marrow." We want the names of the artists. What can we win, Karl?

Just... Just, can I just, um, recap that story? Karl went on a blind date. But when he found out that this girl had some sort of bone marrow problem, he said he didn't want to see her anymore. "What's the point in getting to know someone that's going to die?"
Yeah.
So just, that's what you're dealing with. THAT is what you're dealing with with Karl Pilkington.
Would you buy a car with a duff engine?
[Ricky and Steve laugh]
It's a fair point. ricky.gervais at xfm.co.uk.

Don't steal our sun - The Thrills on Xfm 104.9. I'm Ricky Gervais with me Steve Merchant, over there Karl Pilkington, The man who believes anything. I think it might be a condition due to his little round head. It might be a new condition we can call cranial spherity. and it, cause it's, it presses on his lobes and the only sort of upshot of that is he's normal everywhere but he believes everything he reads or sees on an Ananova. All right?
Talking of which Rick I don't really follow the news it's mainly boring innit Wars and stuff

Well, yeah, when is a war, it's all this nonsense before and after when it's a war it's you know, it's in the middle of the war you can watch it on telly to get results, but I mean like, you know what I mean? Like a test match or summat but It's all this rubbish before and after it drags on
This recent War seemed, I thought just generally it was better presented than the previous one because I remember the first gulf war, it was often during the night and I couldn't stay up and stuff.

Yeah, because I think the American had rights to it that the Tyson fight so we had to get at two in the morning which was annoying they had it their prime time and that and a lot of it was in black and white as well when the bombs went in so err no
This time it seemed a lot more colorful.
Yeah It's much better coverage. I think there should be Awards.
Yeah well I'd like to see awards for it
Like channel four one for Cricket.
Yeah I mean the few times as weel I was quite pleased to see that they actually had footage of the bombs exploding.

Yeah, yeah yeah yeah yeah no, good, Well done. Good on ya, well done, good on ya. Costs a lot though dunnit? Wars a lot more, when you've got summat like, you know a Jimmy Carr game show which probably costs 100 grand, like half an hour War costs millions man
It's almost as expensive as like Terminator 3 or something.
Yeah, but I mean, you know, but you gotta have variety sorry Steve you're talking mate
I just wanted to make sure you were aware that the world elephant polo championships have taken place
I did get it, I heard it mentioned on, we won didn't we?
England won
Yeah
My question is where have they been practising?
I don't know
Do you remember at school anyone asking you are you interested in playing polo with elephants
Do you reckon it was five blokes in pith helmets sneaking into Whipsnade?
Possibly
What you doing lads? We're practising. Get down, get off that elephant
I genuinely, I didn't know we had a team. Johnny Wilkinson and the rugby lads they're gonna get MBE's all sorts, the elephant boys, the elephant polo boys, nothing
They're gonna get nothing
I haven't see the Sun talking about them
But you know, to be fair it's not like horse polo, I don't think there's a stick long enough I think the elephants kick it don't they?
I think you might be right, I think they're not allowed to use their tusks
They'd burst it won't they? They go oh, Raheem
Yeah
What do you mean the elephants kick it?
Alright, I've opened a can of worms here. You know um, normal polo on a horse they have like
A stick and that
Mallets
Yeah to whack em right but I think obviously they're too high up, I think, I might be wrong but I'm pretty sure they just train the elephant to kick it
So what, why are people sat on their back? Why not just let 'em have a kick about without...
(Laughs) Imagine that! And why does horse racing have to have a jockey? Why don't they just let the horses go, "onya okay lads onya.
No cheating. On your marks, get set, go. You go, get back here. Get back here." Brilliant. Why do you think? Just, I tell you what. Now I, I'm gonna be like a teacher now. Why do you think?
Ugh. They sort of get mixed up which end they sort of go in. Which end they've got to get the ball in.
Sort of. Yeah, yeah.
How do you, how do you sort of steer an elephant as it were? How do you ride an elephant? It seems quite a complicated procedure. I don't imagine they're quite as versatile as a horse.
No, you can't sorta like pull it and its head goes can you?
No. I mean I don't really know how you. I mean you'd have to have a huge playing surface wouldn't you? I mean, these are big creatures.
Yeah. They, they use Kent.
Well exactly.
Yeah, and they drop two big, huge jumpers.
Hah yeah, yeah, yeah.
Either side. One in ahh, yeah. South Kent, one in North Kent. And it takes days and days.
And is there, is there the full, is there like 11 on each team?
Yeah, and one on the subs bench.
Exactly.
And it, it keeps breaking. The bench is broken. Terrible.
(laughs) Yeah. He's livid because he's never getting chosen.
He's never, he's never getting chosen, yeah. Well, he hasn't turned up to training.
Of course and he's never gonna forget.
He's been down at the lake.
Exactly.
Down at the lake, when they should be training. Eating too many buns, like Gascoigne.
Exactly.
Right Karl, come on then.
Oh hang on. Now I just must tell you as well about Lord Admiral Nelson's erotic letters.
Go on.
They've been sold at last. For one hundred and seventeen thousand pounds.
Sunday Mail?
I don't know who bought them.
Who opened them that shouldn't've?
They got sent to someone else.
Hang on. They weren't even addressed to you.
They were meant for Lady Hamilton, what are you doing opening 'em?
Go on then, what's he say? What's he get up to?
It's interesting because they've printed a couple of the things he's wrote.
"Dear Lady Hamilton, ahh bit of a problem. Ahh just the one hand. You might have to help me out in a couple of manouvres."
Yeah, and the one eye. So I'm not appreciating the 3D.
(Laughs) Exactly. I don't care where you put it.
Yeah, exactly.
Yeah go on.
You'll have to help me guide it in.
You might as well stand across the other side of the room for all the good it'll do me. Go on then.
And of course he ended up kissing Hardy, ahh didn't he?
Did he kiss Hardy or did he ask him and he never did?
Well, I don't know. I don't know about this because I heard that he didn't and it said Kismet, which also means fate. And then I heard that he did say kiss me, kiss me.
Kiss me Hardy.
Hardy. Like, you know, because it, well it creates suspense. I don't know. Is it, is it Kismet or is it kiss me?
Kiss me Hardy. I think his final actual dying breath was 'no tongues.'
Yeah. Yeah. And someone went, "kiss ya what?".
(laughs) Exactly. Yeah. Maybe that was his nickname.
My, my, my name's Smith. "What did you want me to kiss?"
(Laughs) Exactly.
"Kiss me hardy." "I wouldn't have thought so. I'll kiss your lips and you'll be happy with it."
But ahh, yeah.
"I'll touch ya hardy, but I'm not kissing it." Go on.
Couple of quotes from there. Ahh, this is him writing to Lady Hamilton, who he's having an affair with. "I can neither eat nor sleep for thinking of you my dearest love. I never touch, even pudding."
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
Yeah.
Just to catch up.
Er, do you know how we got caught?
What do you mean 'how he got caught? What's -
He lived in.. he lived in a -
He was living in a rubbish dump.
Well, what's up with that? What's -
He was living in a rubbish dump. No one - no one knew he was there, right?
Yeah

He was living off food that had been chucked away so - a lot of people chuck away stuff that isn't off - so you can survive on that. Er, he had a nice little place to sleep and that - an old mattress, that was alright and stuff. Er, got away with it for ten years until he decided to celebrate bonfire night with some fireworks.
Ricky and Steve laugh
Can you believe that?
Well, you know, he's happy that the, er, gunpowder plot was foiled, and that Guy Fawkes was beheaded -
Anyway...
- thus saving our system of government.
There's got to be a couple of news headlines, surely?
Erm...
Hold on, wait a minute. Bong!
Pierced penis man off the hook.
Bong!
Man changes name to Bubba Bubba Bu-bubba.
Ricky and Steve laugh.
Bong!
Dwarf to live in a glass box.
Ricky and Steve laugh
'Dwarf to live in a glass box'?
Yeah, it's meant to be art or something. It's not though, is it?
What? 'Meant to be art'? Why's - yeah - who's idea is this? Is it his art, or has someone hired a dwarf to live in their box?
It's just a box. And he can even leave when he wants, apparently, he can, like, go 'Oh, i'm hungry, I'm going for a walk.' And he puts a little note -
He could - well, if it's Damien Hirst, he might end up in four bits. So, just be careful.
But to me, that's like that thing when I said to you about the woman in the jar.
What woman in a jar?
The women in a jar. They go 'Ooh, come and see the women in a jar'. And then it turns out it's a big jar. So it's like, well -
[interrupting] Yeah, it's a big jar. Yeah, it's a big jar. Yeah.
- put me in there as well then.
Exactly, yeah.
It's not special.
Yeah.
And that's the same with him. It's a big box, he's a small fella. What's, what's good about that?
What do you want to do though? To compress matter?
But hang on, it's not a world record breaking attempt. It's supposed to be art.
What's art about that?
Well i'm not gonna try and justify it.
[interrupting, laughing] 'What's art about that?'! Oh, can we do a show for BBC Three? Karl Pilkington going round, 'What's Art About That?'
Yeah.
That is brilliant - 'What's Art About That?'
I'd love that.
Would you?
I'd love that.
Me and Steve were gonna do a thing called 'Is Art Rubbish?', where we'd go round and we'd chat about it.
Yeah.

But I'm, well, we can hand that over to you if you want to do that. If anyone from BBC Three's listening, Karl Pilkington - [IN KARL'S VOICE] 'What's Art About That? Alright? Weird innit?' And what, would you go around like Sensation and things like that, and Saatchi, and going -
Dali and that.
- [IN KARL'S VOICE] 'put a sheep in formaldehyde, what's art about that? Our butcher does it. Ah, alright? Ah, weird innit? Ahh.'
What do you make of Dali and the melting clocks, all that stuff?
Talked about it haven't we?
Have we?
Told you, yeah. Told you about -
What do you think of that?
Er, he sort of milked the idea a bit.
Ha! Right.
Yeah, sure.
'Cos everything had a melted clock on it.
Yeah.
It was like he had a bit of success with it once and then he just ruined it, do you know what I mean? It's like -
It's like you with the monkeys.
Like Status Quo.
Yeah, or... yeah.
Sure. What's your favourite artist? Don't say Lowry.
Lowry is me favourite artist.
Why? Why is Lowry your favourite artist?
Captures life, doesn't he? Going on and that.
In stick form.
I know you're a big fan of Where's Wally as well, aren't you?
Ricky laughs
You never found him, have you? Never found him yet...
No karl, that's not [inaudible], it's sustaining on the table - you've come off the book again.
Listen, are we err, are we doing whatsit in a bit?
WHAT? what, what, we don't know what you're talking about!
Play a record!
Yeah we'll be doing whatsit in a minute.
Yeah, whatsit coming up, after the break ehhhh
The film thing.
The film thing.... ohhhh, idiot.
Libertines - Don't look back into the sun
Libertines, please don't look back into the sun on Xfm. 104.9 I'm Ricky Gervais with me Stephen Merchant and Karl Pilkington, Karl. Have we got the results?
Yep.
Go on then, what are they?
Uhhhhh,
Play it again.
Okay, songs of phrase.
This was the phrase, these were the songs.
Song starts playing - Myyyyyyyyy, girlfriend! Haad-PROBLEM with herrr MARRROW.
My girlfriend of the problem with the marrow the answers: Sinatra, Prince, Billy-uh Bill Medley, errr, U2, Shirelles was also dub pistols in there and that.
No one got all of them Karl obviously, but we'll give it to Mark Kantan he got, what did he get, about six or something?
Yep
Well done, he's from Dublin, so that's nice. (Poor Irish accent) Listening over there, the Irish.
Yep.
Alright.
Umm, a German man. Just thought I'd let you know this Karl, Ricky has been arrested because he taught his dog...
To give the Nazi salute, and then he made it do it in front of two policemen. I think it's an offense in that Germany. Now - that's a fascist with too much time on their hands.
No but is it... it's illegal for a dog to do is well?
I think so.
I bet he thought you'd found a loophole.
Yeah.
I mean he's been dying to do it, but he thought well, I'm not allowed to do it. It's illegal for a human to do it.
Yeah.
Thought he got around it and no... dogs...
For a while it just kept doing the Bazil Faulty funny walk. He was going "No!!"
Don't do that!
Don't do the legs as well. The reason I mention it is because he's German...
What were you telling me earlier where.. Karl was wittering on about the Germans earlier. He was saying something about the accent.
Erm.
It's fine with blokes but not with women. You want to go out with a German woman, because the accent.
Was just saying it's a bit manly, isn't it?
Sure
Is it?!
Yeah, it sounds a bit hard. I can't imagine having a nice sort of romantic chat with someone.
Well, it's not a romantic language no, it's quite harsh. Yeah, but that's our...
No but what I mean is right, I can't speak any other languages apart from this one.
Well...
You're struggling with this one.
Yeah.
And what I mean is...
Whereas you really do speak the language of love.
"Alright, here's some condoms. Where's my tea?"
Yeah.
What I'm saying is if a French woman was talking to me I'd say I don't know what you're talking about love but it sounds good. Whereas the German, German woman?
Yep
I'd go Oof. She might be saying really nice stuff.
Yeah.
That's what I mean. But then we got talking because you know like me brother...
Sort of a prejudice really!
In a sense...
What you mean?!
In a sense it's racist. But anyway, on you go...
Yeah go on.
It's not really is it.
No.
But, uhhh. Yeah my brother was in the Army we talked about it haven't we?
Yep
And how he got kicked out for going for packet of fags in a tank.
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]

synopsis.description: German man teaches his dog to do the Nazi salute.
Karl thinks the German accent is fine with blokes but not with women.
